full_conversation: Therapist: Welcome, Mr. Lee. How are you feeling today?
Client: I'm... nervous, Dr. Johnson. I know we're going to talk about the trafficking incident, and I'm not sure I'm ready.
Therapist: That's understandable. Remember, you're safe here.
Client: I know, but just thinking about it makes my heart race. It's been 15 years, but it feels like yesterday.
Therapist: Take a deep breath. We'll go at your pace.
Client: Okay... I'll try. It was a hot summer day when I first met them. They promised me a job overseas, a chance to support my family. I was so naive...
Therapist: You're doing well. Continue when you're ready.

Client: They took my passport as soon as we landed. Said it was for safekeeping. I should have known then, but I was desperate. The factory was... it was hell. We worked 18-hour days, no breaks, barely any food.
Therapist: Stay with that memory. You're safe now.

Client: I can still smell the chemicals, hear the machines whirring. There were others like me, all of us trapped. I remember a young boy, couldn't have been more than 12. He collapsed one day, and they... they just dragged him away. We never saw him again.
Therapist: That must have been terrifying. You're doing great.
Client: It was. I... I can't... The foreman, he would beat us if we slowed down. I still have scars on my back. Sometimes, I wake up feeling the lashes...
Therapist: It's okay to feel this way. You're very brave.
Client: I don't feel brave. I feel weak. I should have fought back, should have found a way to escape sooner.
Therapist: You survived. That takes immense strength.
Client: Maybe. But the guilt... the others I left behind. I managed to slip away during a shipment, but so many others couldn't. Their faces haunt me every night.
Therapist: It's not your fault. You did what you had to.
Client: I know that logically, but emotionally... it's hard. I've built a life here, but I feel like I'm living a lie. Like I don't deserve this freedom.
Therapist: You absolutely deserve it. Keep going.
Client: Sometimes, I think about reaching out to organizations that fight trafficking. Maybe I could help. But then the fear takes over. What if they find me? What if they hurt my family back home?
Therapist: Your safety is important. We can explore safe ways to help.
Client: I suppose. It's just... I feel so alone. How can anyone understand what I've been through? How can I ever have a normal relationship when this is always in the background?
Therapist: You're not alone. There's support available.
Client: I hope so. I'm tired of feeling like this, Dr. Johnson. Tired of the nightmares, the constant looking over my shoulder. I want to feel... normal.
Therapist: It's a process, but you're making progress.
Client: Am I? Sometimes it feels like I'm stuck. Like I'll never move past this.
Therapist: Each session is a step forward. You're doing well.

Client: I guess... It's just hard to see it sometimes. There are days when I can almost forget, and then something small triggers everything. A certain smell, a loud noise, and suddenly I'm back there.
Therapist: That's common with trauma. We'll work on coping strategies.
Client: I hope they help. I'm just so tired of living like this, always on edge. I want to be able to trust people again, to feel safe in my own skin.
Therapist: That's a good goal. We'll work towards it together.
Client: Thank you, Dr. Johnson. I know it's not easy listening to all this.
Therapist: You're very welcome. Our time is almost up. How are you feeling?
Client: Drained, but... maybe a little lighter? Is that strange?
Therapist: Not at all. It's a common reaction. You did very well today.
Client: Thank you. Same time next week?
Therapist: Yes, I'll see you then. Take care, Mr. Lee.
